knowledge_graph.title: Saffron
knowledge_graph.description: Saffron is a spice derived from the flower of Crocus sativus, commonly known as the "saffron crocus". The vivid crimson stigma and styles, called threads, are collected and dried for use mainly as a seasoning and colouring agent in food.

related_questions.question: What does saffron do to your body?
related_questions.snippet: Saffron is a brightly-colored spice that's high in health-promoting compounds, such as carotenoid antioxidants. Research findings suggest saffron has anti-inflammatory and antioxidant effects and may improve heart health, reduce symptoms of depression and anxiety, improve sleep, and protect eye health.
related_questions.title: Saffron Health Benefits, According to a Dietitian

related_questions.question: What is the main use of saffron?
related_questions.snippet: Overview. Saffron (Crocus sativus) is a plant. The dried thread-like parts of the flower (stigmas) are used to make saffron spice, food coloring, and medicine. Saffron contains chemicals that might alter mood, kill cancer cells, decrease swelling, and act like antioxidants.
related_questions.title: SAFFRON - Uses, Side Effects, and More - WebMD

related_questions.question: What is saffron and why is it so expensive?
related_questions.snippet: The part of the flower that is used to make the spice is the reddish-brown threads found in the flower. Nussbaum says it's expensive because of how it's harvested. “It's super, super expensive and that's because it's actually from the stigma of a flower, and it's really difficult to harvest,” she explains.
related_questions.title: What is saffron? Medical use, cooking and why it's expensive - USA Today

related_questions.question: What does saffron even taste like?
related_questions.snippet: What Does Saffron Taste Like? Saffron has a subtle earthy-sweet flavor profile with a tinge of bitterness on the tongue that gives way to delicate floral and honey notes. Fresh saffron smells a little like sweet hay mixed with freshly mown grass, with a whiff of pepper.
related_questions.title: What Is Saffron? | Cooking School - Food Network

organic_results.snippet: Saffron is the stigma of the crocus flower and is the most expensive spice in the world. 70,000 of these flowers must be hand picked to produce one pound.

buttons.subtitle: Why Is Saffron Used In Cooking
buttons.title: What Is Saffron? | Cooking School - Food Network
buttons.snippet: In culinary applications, saffron is used as a spice to flavor dishes or as natural yellow dye. Outside of food, saffron extracts are used to dye textiles or added to fragrances. Saffron is a common ingredient in Indian, Moroccan and Iranian cuisines.
snippet_highlighted_words: as a spice to flavor dishes or as natural yellow dye

buttons.subtitle: Price Of Saffron
buttons.title: Pure Saffron (Kesar), 5 GM - PureMart
buttons.snippet: Pure Saffron or Kashmiri Kesar is one of the priciest spices available on 'Earth'. 1 KG Saffron (Kesar) price is around Rs. 3,00,000. From antiquity to modern times the history of saffron is full of applications in food, drink, and traditional herbal medicine.
snippet_highlighted_words: 1 KG Saffron (Kesar) price is around Rs.

buttons.subtitle: Why Is Saffron The Most Expensive Spice?
buttons.title: Why Is Saffron So Expensive? - Britannica
buttons.snippet: Since such a small part of the flower is used, it takes 75,000 saffron flowers to make one pound of saffron spice. The small amount of saffron spice per plant, along with the fact that harvesting must be done manually, leads to saffron's being majorly expensive.
snippet_highlighted_words: The small amount of saffron spice per plant, along with the fact that harvesting must be done manually

buttons.subtitle: Saffron Substitute
buttons.title: What are substitutes for saffron threads in a recipe? - Quora
buttons.snippet: Ground turmeric is the best substitute for saffron and it's easy to find at your local grocery store. Some other substitute options include annatto or safflower, but these ingredients are pretty tough to find. In our opinion, turmeric is your best option!
